newsitem.title: USA: EEOC sues health company for language curb.
newsitem.headline: EEOC sues health company for language curb.

text.p: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission Monday sued a home health care provider for its "Speak English Only" policy and for allegedly firing Hispanic-American workers who objected to it.

The suit, filed in Manhattan federal court, was brought on behalf of two women who alleged that Brooklyn, New York-based Long Life Home Care Service fired them shortly after a supervisor met with them to discuss "speaking Spanish on the job."
Long Life, which employes some 1,500 workers, does not dispute the existence of its policy prohibiting speaking of a language other than English during working hours, the EEOC said.
However, the two plaintiffs alleged that the policy even prohibited employees from speaking Spanish during breaks, lunch in the cafeteria and within one city block of Long Life's office building.
The company could not be reached for comment.
